awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High-mix, Low-volume PCB Assembly System
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The most basic designs can be breadboarded, but most involve more complex circuits, or must be housed in confined spaces, requiring realization on printed circuit boards (PCB). This MRI award supported Florida Atlantic University (FAU) in acquiring a printed circuit board assembly system optimized for a high-mix, low-volume research prototyping environment and having a new capability to manufacture or assemble modern printed circuit boards. The assembly system has supported a variety of projects, including the design, implementation, and evaluation of (i) a practical solution for underwater localization and communication, (ii) a new approach to GPS-free localization and navigation, (iii) an autonomous optical and acoustic system for underwater imaging, detection, and classification; (iv) an autonomous aerial/terrestrial/water robotics platform for large-scale monitoring of aquaculture fisheries; (v) new hardware platforms for perpetual, battery-free sensing under dynamic load and energy availability conditions; (vi) utility-scale technologies for harvesting hydrokinetic energy from ocean currents; among numerous others yet to be articulated.

The intellectual merit of this project stems from the research activities enabled by the instrument. Examples of research projects powered by FAU’s new PCB assembly system include the design, implementation, and evaluation of (i) a low-cost, high-fidelity, wireless sensing system for monitoring carbon dioxide concentrations for demand-controlled ventilation, (ii) a wireless system for monitoring pressure transients and forecasting pipe leaks in municipal water distribution systems, and (iii) a large-scale atmospheric monitoring system to provides storm surge data to the National Weather Service as part of its forecasting network.

The project's broader impacts extended to educating the next generation of scientists and engineers and supporting a burgeoning entrepreneurial community in South Florida. The assembly system enhanced an existing undergraduate course in electronics and an existing graduate course in embedded design. The system will not only serve as a valuable prototyping tool in each course but also provide a foundation for introducing design-for-manufacturing principles, which are essential in the electronics industry but often neglected in university coursework. The assembly system was also used to support outreach efforts, including high school student groups and prospective graduate students. Finally, the instrument was a focal point for one senior engineering design group, which used the instrument as a model to develop a low-cost, hobbyist unit as part of their final engineering project.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2024
Modified by: Jinwoo Jang
